tit.cmt: 他の記事と表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 木津町（きづちょう）は、京都府相楽郡にあった町。
sen.e: "Kizu-cho" is the name of the town which once existed in Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.
"Kizu-cho" is the name of the town which used to exist in Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kizu-cho is the name of the town which used to exist in Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 2007年3月12日、山城町 (京都府)、加茂町 (京都府)と合併し木津川市となった。
sen.e: On March 12, 2007, Kizu-cho was consolidated with Yamashiro-cho (in Kyoto Prefecture) and Kamo-cho (also in Kyoto Prefecture) into Kizugawa City.
On March 12, 2007, Kizu-cho was consolidated with Yamashiro-cho (in Kyoto Prefecture) and Kamo-cho (also in Kyoto Prefecture) into Kizugawa City.
On March 12, 2007, Kizu-cho was consolidated with Yamashiro-cho (Kyoto Prefecture) and Kamo-cho (Kyoto Prefecture) into Kizugawa City.

sen.j: 現在は存在しない町である。
sen.e: At present, Kizu-cho is not existent any more.
At present, Kizu-cho no longer exists.
At present, Kizu-cho no longer exists.

sen.j: 地理
sen.e: Geography
Geography
Geography

sen.j: 京都府最南端に位置する。
sen.e: The location where Kizu-cho formerly existed is the southern edge of Kyoto Prefecture.
The location where Kizu-cho formerly existed is the southern edge of Kyoto Prefecture.
The location where Kizu-cho formerly existed is the southern edge of Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 木津川 (京都府)が流れており、古くは木材運搬用の港として栄えた（木の津・町名の由来）。
sen.e: The Kizu-gawa River (in Kyoto Prefecture) runs through here, so in the old days this place prospered as a port for lumber transit; the town name "Kizu" comes from the lumber (in Japanese, "ki") & the port (in Japanese, "zu" or "tsu").

The Kizu-gawa River (in Kyoto Prefecture) runs through here, so in the old days this place prospered as a port for lumber transit; the town name "Kizu" comes from the lumber (in Japanese, "ki") & the port (in Japanese, "zu" or "tsu").

The Kizu-gawa River (Kyoto Prefecture) runs through here, so in the old days this place prospered as a port for lumber transit; the town name "Kizu" comes from the lumber (in Japanese, "ki") and the port (in Japanese, "zu" or "tsu").
sen.cmt: in は削除しました。& → and としました。

sen.j: 合併以前から人口増加が著しく、平成17年実施国勢調査速報値によると、増加率は日本国内町村の中で6位（当時）であり、2006年3月10日に4万人を越えた。
sen.e: Even before the consolidation with two other towns, the population growth here was remarkable, and so, for example, the prompt report of the national census in 2005 says the growth rate ranked the sixth of all towns and villages in Japan (at that time), and the population exceeded 40,000 on March 10, 2006.

Even before the consolidation with two other towns, the population growth here was remarkable. A report from the national census in 2005 says the growth rate ranked sixth out of all towns and villages in Japan (at that time), and the population exceeded 40,000 on March 10, 2006.

Even before the consolidation with two other towns, the population growth here was remarkable; a report from the national census in 2005 says the growth rate ranked sixth out of all towns and villages in Japan (at that time), and the population exceeded 40,000 on March 10, 2006.

sen.j: 関西文化学術研究都市（学研都市）の一部であり、研究施設が建ち並ぶ地区もあるが、古い街並みと豊かな自然の残る地区が多い。
sen.e: The former Kizu-cho area constitutes a part of Kansai Science City (Gakken Toshi), so it has a district where research facilities stand side by side, but it also has many districts where the row of old houses and rich nature are still left intact.

The former Kizu-cho area constitutes a part of Kansai Science City (Gakken Toshi), so it has a district where research facilities stand side by side, but it also has many districts where rows of old houses and rich nature are still left intact.

The former Kizu-cho area constitutes a part of Kansai Science City (Gakken Toshi), so it has a district where research facilities stand side by side, but it also has many districts where rows of old houses and rich nature are still left intact.

sen.j: 柿が特産。
sen.e: The Japanese persimmon is the specialty here.
The Japanese persimmon is the specialty here.
The Japanese persimmon is the specialty here.

sen.j: 「自然と伝統を生かし、文化を創造する調和のとれたふれあいのまち」を町の標語に掲げていた。
sen.e: Kizu-cho once held the watchword, "the town of nature & tradition which are both harmonized with the newly created culture, and which you can contact with."
Kizu-cho once held the watchword, "the town of nature & tradition which are both harmonized with the newly created culture, and which you can contact with."
Kizu-cho once held the watchword, 'the town of nature and tradition which are both harmonized with the newly created culture, and which you can contact with.'
sen.cmt: & → and としました。" → ' としました。

sen.j: 1889年（明治22年）4月1日 町村制施行により相楽郡に木津村が置かれる。
sen.e: April 1, 1889 - With the town-village administrative system put into effect, "Kizu-mura" (Kizu Village) was created in "Soraku-gun" (Soraku County).
April 1, 1889 - With the town-village administrative system put into effect, "Kizu-mura" (Kizu Village) was created in "Soraku-gun" (Soraku County).
April 1, 1889: With the town-village administrative system put into effect, Kizu-mura was created in Soraku-gun.
sen.cmt: " " は削除しました。「"On"を使わない日付+半角コロン+半角スペース+文章」の形式に変更しました。

sen.j: 1893年（明治26年）11月25日 町制施行により木津町となる。
sen.e: November 25, 1893 - With the town administrative system put into effect, Kizu-mura became Kizu-cho.
November 25, 1893 - With the town administrative system put into effect, Kizu-mura became Kizu-cho.
November 25, 1893: With the town administrative system put into effect, Kizu-mura became Kizu-cho.

sen.j: 1951年（昭和26年）4月1日 相楽郡相楽村（そうらくぐん・さがなかむら）を編入。
sen.e: April 1, 1951 - "Saganaka-mura" (Saganaka Village) in Soraku-gun was incorporated into Kizu-cho.
April 1, 1951 - "Saganaka-mura" (Saganaka Village) in Soraku-gun was incorporated into Kizu-cho.
April 1, 1951: Saganaka-mura in Soraku-gun was incorporated into Kizu-cho.
sen.cmt: 同上 " " は削除しました。

sen.j: 2007年（平成19年）3月12日 相楽郡木津町、加茂町、山城町の3町合併により木津川市となる。
sen.e: March 12, 2007, Kizu-cho, Kamo-cho and Yamashiro-cho, which had all belonged to Soraku-gun until then, were consolidated into Kizugawa City.
March 12, 2007, Kizu-cho, Kamo-cho and Yamashiro-cho, which had all belonged to Soraku-gun until then, were consolidated into Kizugawa City.
March 12, 2007: Kizu-cho, Kamo-cho and Yamashiro-cho, which had all belonged to Soraku-gun until then, were consolidated into Kizugawa City.

sen.j: ロート製薬、オムロン、積水ハウス総合住宅研究所などの民間研究施設ならびに、きっづ光科学館ふぉとん（日本原子力研究開発機構 関西光科学研究所）、ATR等の国の研究施設が立地。
sen.e: There stand not only private research facilities, such as Rohto Research Village Kyoto, Omron Corporation Keihanna Technology Innovation Center and Sekisui House Co.,Ltd. Comprehensive Housing R & D Institute, but also national research facilities, such as the Kids' Science Museum of Phtons operated by Kansai Photon Science Institute which belongs to Japan Atomic Energy Agency, and Adavanced Telecommunications Research Institute International (ATR).

The area is home not only to private research facilities, such as Rohto Research Village Kyoto, Omron Corporation Keihanna Technology Innovation Center and Sekisui House Co.,Ltd. Comprehensive Housing R & D Institute, but also national research facilities, such as the Kids' Science Museum of Phtons operated by Kansai Photon Science Institute which belongs to Japan Atomic Energy Agency, and Adavanced Telecommunications Research Institute International (ATR).

The area is home not only to private research facilities, such as Rohto Research Village Kyoto, Omron Corporation Keihanna Technology Innovation Center and Sekisui House Co., Ltd. sen.j: 木津駅は交通の要衝であり、2007年（平成19年）春の橋上駅供用開始と合わせて、駅東口の設置が進められている。
sen.e: Kizu Station is a transportation hub, so the eastern entrance of the station is under construction to meet the schedule that the station building will center its functions on the second floor and restart its operation in spring of 2007.
sen.cmt: ※「橋上駅」とは、「（改札口や自動券売機など）その機能を2階部分に集中させた駅舎」のことであり（Wiki 「橋上駅」参照）、翻訳でもそのように表現しています。
sen.e: Kizu Station is a transportation hub, with the eastern entrance of the station under construction in schedule with the start of operations on the second floor of the station building in spring of 2007.

sen.j: 木津三社祭り（木津町指定文化財（無形民俗）の登録名称は「木津布団太鼓台祭」）
sen.e: Kizu Sansha Matsuri Festival : Its registered name as the designated cultural asset of Kizu-cho (the intangible folk custom) is "Kizu Futon Daikodai Matsuri Festival."
Kizu Sansha Matsuri Festival : Its registered name as the designated cultural asset of Kizu-cho (the intangible folk custom) is "Kizu Futon Daikodai Matsuri Festival."
Kizu Sansha Matsuri Festival : Its registered name as the designated cultural asset of Kizu-cho (the intangible folk custom) is "Kizu Futon Daikodai Matsuri Festival."

sen.j: 10月の第4土曜日と翌日曜日。
sen.e: In principle the festival is held on the fourth Satuaday & Sunday of October every year.
sen.cmt: ※次に続く文章との関係上、冒頭に「原則として」と補っています。
sen.e: In principle the festival is held on the fourth Satuaday & Sunday of October every year.
In principle the festival is held on the fourth Saturday and Sunday of October every year.
sen.cmt: & → and としました。スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 但し、10月20日、21日が土日の場合は20、21日。
sen.e: But if October 20 and 21 fall on Saturday and Sunday, the festival is exceptionally held on these dates.
But if October 20 and 21 fall on Saturday and Sunday, the festival is held as an exception on these dates.
But if October 20 and 21 fall on Saturday and Sunday, the festival is held as an exception on these dates.

sen.j: 御霊神社・岡田国神社・田中神社の三神社に6基の布団太鼓を宮入する（敬神組、社町、小寺町、西町、義友会、拝神團）
sen.e: Six "Futon Daiko" (peculiar bass drums) are carried into the precincts of Goryo-jinja Shrine, Okadakuni-jinja Shrine, and Tanaka-jinja Shrine by men of Keishin-gumi, Yashiro-cho, Kodera-cho, Nishi-cho, Giyu-kai, or Haishin-dan.
sen.cmt: ※「宮入（みやいり）」とは「祭礼の練り物を神社の境内に繰り込むこと」（goo辞書参照）ということを踏まえて訳しました。
sen.e: Six "Futon Daiko" (peculiar bass drums) are carried into the precincts of Goryo-jinja Shrine, Okadakuni-jinja Shrine, and Tanaka-jinja Shrine by men of Keishin-gumi, Yashiro-cho, Kodera-cho, Nishi-cho, Giyu-kai, or Haishin-dan.

Six "Futon Daiko" (peculiar bass drums) are carried into the precincts of Goryo-jinja Shrine, Okadakuni-jinja Shrine, and Tanaka-jinja Shrine by men of Keishin-gumi, Yashiro-cho, Kodera-cho, Nishi-cho, Giyu-kai, or Haishin-dan.
